page.title: 18LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: The earliest traces of man in our area probably date from 250B.C.when Maesbury Castle was used as a hill fort to retreat into when danger threatened. Another such site is at Gurney Slade Bottom. This was followed by the Romans who crossed our area with roads taking lead from Charterhouse to the rest of the country. Parts of the modern roads still follow the path of these roads and they can be traced across fields. The land was open until the enclosures of the late 18th. century and the fields today are much the same size as they were then. Quarrying for stone and the brewery followed closely by the railway were the next to change the landscape. The railway line can still be traced, as can the old foot paths that cross the fields marked by the Somerset stone stiles.
